clinical_study.brief_title: Early Debridement Within 24 Hours After Surgery for Wound Healing of Abdominal Incision
clinical_study.official_title: Early Debridement Within 24 Hours After Surgery Compared Routine Debridement (24 Hours Later) for Wound Healing of Abdominal Incision

lead_sponsor.agency: First Affiliated Hospital Xi'an Jiaotong University

clinical_study.source: First Affiliated Hospital Xi'an Jiaotong University

brief_summary.textblock: Wound healing after surgery is a complex procedure. Liquefaction of the fat and necrosis of inactivated tissue, as well as blood clots are always accumulated mostly within 24 hours after surgery. As such, early debridement within 24 hours after surgery might improve the healing of the wounds. This study is designed to compare the impact of early debridement of the wound versus regular dressing (24 hours later) on the wound healing. 100 patients will be included in this study, and divided into 2 groups randomly. Then, the healing of the wound, stitch removal time, incidence of incision complications will be compared between the two groups.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of surgery to the date of stitches off (up to 1 month)
primary_outcome.description: since the ending of surgery to stitches off.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the date of surgery to stitches off (up to 1 month)
secondary_outcome.description: The incision complications include infection, dehiscence, fat liquefaction, etc.

arm_group.description: The subjects in this group will be debrided within 24 hours after surgery.
The subjects in this group will experience wound dressing change regularly 24 hours after surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- the patient with major abdominal incision.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman
- Patient with diabetes
- Patient with a history of cardiovascular disease, including coronary heart disease and stroke.
- Severe lung diseases such as COPD and asthma
- Patients undergoing emergent surgery or infectious surgery
- Patients with surgical site infection or abdominal abscess
- No autonomy, inability or unwillingness to participate in follow-up
